questions.text:
Match the following instruments used in surgery.
  1. Allis tissue forceps
  2. Lane’s tissue holding forceps
  3. Kocher’s hemostatic forceps
  4. Babcock’s forceps
questions.solution:
Option 2 is correctly matched.

Image 1 shows Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

 

Image 2 shows Allis tissue forceps.

  • Distal blades are not opposing each other
  • Tip has got teeth in each blade which are opposing
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold Skin flaps, Fascia, Aponeurosis, Bladder wall.

 

Image 3 shows Babcock’s forceps where:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc.

 

Image 4 shows Kocher’s hemostatic forceps.

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments would be best suited to retract the liver out of the field of operation while performing an open cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
The Deaver’s retractor would be most useful in cholecystectomy as it is specifically designed for holding the liver up and out of the way.

Deaver’s retractor is used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. Some surgeons protect the liver with an abdominal pack before placing the blade on top.

Doyen's retractor - It is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder for proper exposure of the lower uterine segment during a cesarian section.

Morris retractor is a large retractor useful for providing maximum exposure in large incisions e.g., abdominal incisions. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Czerny's retractor - This is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?
  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Of the given list/combination of instruments 1, 2, 4, 6 are commonly used in the cesarean section. 

Cesarean section is an operative procedure in which the fetuses are delivered through an incision on the abdominal and uterine walls. 

The given image summarizes the various instruments used in the lower segment cesarean section.

 

Bard-Parker blade (scalpel with blade) has a handle with a notch to fit the blade. It is usually held by pencil grip. Commonly for abdominal incisions, we use blade no: 22. Other uses include incision of skin and sub-cutaneous tissues, cutting the clamped pedicles, and performing sharp dissections. 

The given image shows various Bard-Parker blades.

 

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor. 

 

Alli's forceps: It is identified by the distal blades and a tip that has teeth that do not oppose each other. There is also a lock in the proximal part. 

Uses:

  • To catch hold of the margins and angles of the uterine flaps in LSCS after the delivery of the baby in settings where the Green-Armytage hemostatic clamp is not available.
  • To catch hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • To hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during the repair.
  • To catch hold of the margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa during the repair.
  • To catch hold of the torn ends of the sphincter ani externus prior to suture in the repair of complete perineal tear.

The given image shows Alli's forceps.

 

Green armytage forceps have a broad tip as shown in the image and hence are used to compress a wide area. It is used as a hemostat in caesarian sections. In LSCS (Lower segment Caesarean section), the cut uterine edges can bleed and Green Armytage forceps are applied to the edge of the incision for hemostasis.

 

Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualization of the cervix, vaginal fornices, and for performing pap smears.

The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum.

 

Shirodkar's uterine holding clamp has blades with curved transverse bars with gaps between them when it is locked. This gap makes it atraumatic and is used to lift, hold and steady the uterus during sling surgeries and tubal procedures. 

The image below shows Shirodkar's uterine clamp.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: You enter the ENT operation theatre when a procedure is underway for a patient with fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.  You notice the following instruments on the instruments tray. Which of the following is not an indication for the procedure performed with these instruments?
questions.solution:
The given image is of instruments commonly used in Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) operation. Lateral frontal sinus disease is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery as the disease is inaccessible by endoscopic procedures.

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis).
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polyp.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.

Contraindications to FESS:

  • Inexperience and lack of proper instrumentation.
  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, e.g. lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis.
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication.

questions.text: A 55-year-old, alcohol-dependent male patient presented with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. The patient reports that this is a recurring problem even after repeated medical interventions. On auscultation, basal crackles are heard bilaterally on the chest fields. He is visibly icteric, and his fingers show clubbing. The nurse prepares the following tray for a procedure. Which quadrant of the abdomen is preferred when performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a large-volume paracentesis is to be done to remove ascitic fluid secondary to likely liver pathology. The left lower quadrant is preferred because of the greater depth of ascites and the thinner abdominal wall.

After evaluation of the patient and confirmation of ascites, the etiology of the ascites is best determined by paracentesis. 

Paracentesis is a bedside procedure in which a needle or small catheter is passed transcutaneously to drain ascitic fluid from the peritoneum. The lower quadrant is the most frequent site for paracentesis. The left lower quadrant is preferred because of the greater depth of ascites and the thinner abdominal wall. Paracentesis is a relatively safe procedure even in patients with coagulopathy.

Complications are seen but are infrequent and include the following:

  • Abdominal wall hematomas
  • Hypotension
  • Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Infection

Refractory cirrhotic ascites is defined by the persistence of ascites despite sodium restriction and maximal (or maximally tolerated) diuretic use. When medical therapy is insufficient, refractory ascites is managed by repeated large-volume paracentesis (LVP). Patients undergoing LVP should receive IV albumin infusions of 6–8 g per liter of ascitic fluid removed. Intravenous infusion of albumin accompanying LVP decreases the risk of “post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction” and death. Post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction (PPCD) is characterized by the activation of the RAAS system and increased renin levels. It causes rapid re-accumulation of ascitic fluid.

Indications of paracentesis:

  • Diagnostic -
    • New-onset ascites for fluid evaluation
    • Refractory ascites
    • Suspected spontaneous or secondary bacterial peritonitis
  • Therapeutic -
    • Respiratory compromise secondary to ascites
    • Abdominal pain or pressure secondary to ascites

Contraindications :

An acute abdomen requiring surgery is the only absolute contraindication. Relative contraindications include elevated PT/INR and pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is/are used in tubal patency testing?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. All the above instruments are used in tubal patency testing. 

Image 1 shows Rubins Insufflation Cannula.

It requires a ‘Y’ rubber tube. One end is attached to a bulb and the other end to a manometer.

Uses: To know the patency of the tube (Rubin’s test) in infertility investigation or following tuboplasty.

 

Image 2 shows Cervical occlusion clamp.

  • The blades are guarded with rubber tubes to avoid trauma to tissues.
  • Cervix is occluded with the instrument and methylene blue dye is injected into the uterine cavity through the fundus using a syringe and a needle.

Uses: Evaluation of tubal patency during laparotomy (following tuboplasty).

 

Image 3 shows Hysterosalpingographic cannula.

It is required to push the iodine containing radio-opaque dye (urograffin) into the uterus during hysterosalpingography.

Uses:

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate tubal patency.
  • Hydrotubation.

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following materials to perform a procedure. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization. 

The materials are as follows according to their numbers in the given image.

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Sterile gel for ultrasound guidance
  4. Introducer needle (here 18 Ga) on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  5. Guidewire
  6. Tissue dilator
  7. An indwelling catheter (here 16 Ga)
  8. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread
  9. The final dressing to be applied

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Preferred sites in special considerations :

  • Severe bleeding diatheses - Internal/external jugular vein
  • Severe emphysema - Internal jugular
  • Emergency transvenous cardiac pacing - Right internal jugular
  • Trauma patients (neck immobilised) - Subclavian/Femoral

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrated vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids (Trauma, major surgery)
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are kept in the baby tray in the labour room ?
  1. Vitamin K
  2. Cotton swabs
  3. Mucus extractor
  4. Epinephrine 
  5. Bag and mask
  6. Cord clamp
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. Epinephrine is not kept in the baby tray.

Baby tray kept in the labour room must contain:

  1. Two pre-warmed towels/sheets for wrapping the baby
  2. Cotton swabs
  3. Mucus extractor
  4. Bag and mask
  5. Sterilized thread for cord/cord clamp
  6. Nasogastric tube
  7. Gloves
  8. Inj. Vitamin K and syringe.

questions.text: Name the surgery for which the following set of instruments is used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used in tonsillectomy.

Instrument 1: Boyle-Davis mouth gag is used for opening the mouth and depressing tongue for doing surgery. Various sized tongue blades are used along with it according to the age of the patient.

Uses of Boyle Davis mouth gag are:

  • Pharyngoplasty
  • Tonsillectomy 
  • Surgery of soft palate
  • Adenoidectomy
  • Excision of angiofibroma

Instrument 2: Draffin’s bipod

Each pod has four rings. They can be assembled to vary the height at which the tongue blade of the Boyle-Davis mouth gag can be suspended. The lower end of each pod can be placed in one of the several depressions in Magauran’s plate (vide infra).

Instrument 3: Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps is used for holding the tonsil during tonsillectomy by dissection method.

Instrument 4: Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor:

One end is used to dissect the tonsil and the other end to retract the anterior pillar to inspect the tonsillar fossa for any bleeding point.

Instrument 5: Eves’ tonsil snare is used for tonsillectomy. After the tonsil has been dissected till its lower pole, snare is passed round the tonsil to engage the pedicle and then firmly closed. It crushes and cuts the pedicle thereby minimizing bleeding. Wire used in snare is number 25 SWG.

Instrument 6: Waugh’s tonsil dissection forceps is used for incision in mucous membrane and dissection of the tonsil.

questions.text: Name the procedure for which the following set of instruments are used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used for dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).

 

Instrument 1 shows Muller's self-retaining lacrimal wound retractor. It is made up of two limbs with three curved pins on each for engaging the edges of the skin incision. The limbs are kept in a retracted position with the help of a fixing screw. It is used to retract the skin during surgery on the lacrimal sac e.g. dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) or dacryocystectomy (DCT).

 Instrument 2 shows Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator. It has a cylindrical corrugated metal handle with a conical pointed tip. It is used to dilate the punctum and canaliculus during syringing, probing, dacryocystography, DCT, and DCR procedures.

 Instrument 3 shows Bowman's lacrimal probe. It has blunt ends with a central stable platform. It is used to:

  • Probe the lacrimal gland in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction
  • Identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

 Instrument 4 shows lacrimal cannula. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. It is used for: 

  • Syringing the lacrimal passages
  • Injecting air, tryphan blue dye, pilocarpine, and balanced salt solution in the anterior chamber during intraocular surgery

Instrument 5 shows a bone punch. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. The upper blade has a small hole with a sharp cutting edge. The lower blade has a cup-like depression. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during DCR operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Instrument 6 shows the chisel. It consists of a blade having a sharp-cutting straight edge with one surface bevelled. It has a long and stout handle. It is used to cut the bone during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 7 shows the hammer. It is a small steel hammer attached to a corrugated handle. It is used to hammer the chisel during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 8 shows the lacrimal sac dissector and curette. It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted. It is used to curette the lacrimal sac in lacrimal sac surgery.

Instrument 9 shows Freer's periosteum elevator. It has a rounded handle with two slightly curved, tear-drop tips. It is used for blunt debulking and lifting periosteum from bones in confined areas. It is used in endoscopic septoplasty and DCR.

questions.text: Identify the procedure for which the given instrument tray is used.
questions.solution:
The given tray contains the Jamshidi biopsy needle which is used to perform bone marrow biopsy.

Jamshidi bone marrow biopsy needle, instrument number 3, is the key identifier.

Equipment: 

  1. Stylet
  2. Cap
  3. Jamshidi Biopsy needle-wide bore.
  4. J-shaped obturator for removing the biopsy core from the needle
  5. No. 11 blade to give a stab at the selected site
  6. Glass slides
  7. Drapes
  8. Sponge holder
  9. Disposable syringes - to give local anesthesia and then to collect samples
  10. Needles - to give local anesthesia and then to collect samples
  11. Bowl for antiseptic solution
  12. Kidney tray
  13. Gauze pieces
  14. Injectable lidocaine 2% for local anesthesia

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia.
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis.
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors.
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias.
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases.
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections or granulomatous diseases.

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: 

  • Severe hemophilia.
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Severe bleeding disorders.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the Obstetrics and Gynaecology outpatient department. You notice the following set of instruments on a tray in the examination room. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the test performed with the given set of instruments?

choices.text: Test should not be performed if the patient has had intercourse in the past 72 hours
Ideal time to perform the test is around the time of ovulation
The test should be performed prior to performing a vaginal examination
Lubricants should not be used while or prior to performing the test

questions.solution:
The given set of instruments are commonly used for the collection of pap smears. The patient should, ideally, not have had intercourse in the 24 hours prior to the test.

The given image includes Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum, Koplin's jar, smear slides, Ayer's spatula, and endocervical brush. 

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination, as the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report,
  • Lubricants should not be used as they may prevent detection of organisms
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test as any vaginal bleeding during the examination precludes proper visualization of the cervix. So, the ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have had intercourse 24 hours prior to the test.

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. 

 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
Match the following splints and the conditions where they are used.
  1. Cervical spine injury
  2. Brachial plexus injury
  3. Radial nerve palsy
  4. Ulnar nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

  1. Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy
  2. Cock-up splint  - Radial nerve palsy
  3. Aeroplane splint - Brachial plexus injury
  4. SOMI Brace - Cervical spine injury

Knuckle bender splint :

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated, the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP (metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Cock-up splint - 

it is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Aeroplane splint:

It is used in the management of brachial plexus injury and axillary nerve injury.

SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used to treat cervical spine injury. 

It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

questions.text: While posted in the COVID ward, you notice the following instruments present on a tray and you realize it is for a particular procedure. All of the following predict difficulty in performing the procedure except:
questions.solution:
The image shows a tray in an airway cart with the instruments necessary for endotracheal intubation. All the options are predictors of difficult laryngoscopy (and difficult intubation) except a long, thin neck. A short, thick neck is a predictor of difficult laryngoscopy.

An endotracheal intubation tray may include:

  1. Magill's forceps 
  2. Macintosh curved laryngoscope/Miller's straight laryngoscope for direct laryngoscopy
  3. Endotracheal (ET) tubes of varying sizes
  4. A 10ml syringe to inflate the bulb of the ET tube
  5. Stylet and Bougie to aid in difficulty with intubation
  6. Guedel oropharyngeal airway to suction secretion for better visualization of the airway

Difficult endotracheal intubation by direct laryngoscopy is primarily due to an inadequate view of the glottis. Predictors for difficult laryngoscopy are as given below :

  • Long upper incisors
  • Prominent overbite
  • Inability to protrude the mandible
  • Small mouth opening
  • Mallampati classification III or IV
  • High, arched palate
  • Short thyromental distance
  • Short, thick neck
  • Limited cervical mobility

The Cormack and Lehane grading scale describes laryngoscopic views with grades ranging from I (the best view) to IV (the most difficult view). The grades are as follows :

Grades Structures visualized
I Entire laryngeal aperture
II Only the posterior portion of the laryngeal aperture
III Only the epiglottis
IV No visualization of the epiglottis or larynx

Yentis modified the classification scheme and proposed that grade II be differentiated into IIA (partial view of the glottis) and IIB (arytenoids or posterior vocal cords only are visible).

  • Grade I or IIA - relatively easy intubation.
  • Grades IIB and III - significantly difficult intubation.
  • Grade IV- alternate method of intubation required (such as blind passage of ET or using an intubating stylet).

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the casualty after a trivial fall with pain in her right hip. X-Rays taken shows the presence of fracture of the femoral neck.  Which of the following implants will the orthopedic surgeon use in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given nails used as implants, the Smith Petersen nail (SP nail) shown in image 1 is used for internal fixation of fracture of the femoral neck.

Smith Petersen nail (SP nail) :

It is a cannulated triflanged nail that is used for internal fixation of a fracture of the neck of the femur. Advantages of its triflanged shape:

  • It prevents axial rotation of the fragments
  • It cuts only a little bone to provide good stability.

The nail is cannulated because it is threaded over a guide wire introduced at the correct site under X-ray control. It can be used along with McLaughlin’s plate for the fixation of inter-trochanteric fractures as well.

Other options :

Image 2 shows Ender’s nail. This is used for internal fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur.

 

Option C) - The given image shows a Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail)

Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail) is used for the treatment of femoral fractures. It is based on the concept of three-point fixation i.e., at either end and at the isthmus. The eye at the end of the nail is useful while removing it. The Cloverleaf shape on the cross-section which provides good rotational stability

Some common complications of K-nailing:

  • Nail getting stuck
  • Splintering of the cortex while hammering the nail
  • Proximal migration of the nail, leading to bursitis over its protruding end
  • Distal migration of the nail leading to stiffness of the knee
  • Infection

Image 3 shows Talwalkar square nail. This is used for fractures of forearm bones

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the procedure performed with the following set of instruments?

choices.text: Best placement of the tube for suctioning is postpyloric
It is contraindicated in significant facial trauma
Length is measured from tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm position

questions.solution:
The given instrument tray shows instruments required for insertion of a nasogastric tube which is placed before the pylorus when used for suction to avoid damage to the duodenum.

Nasogastric tubes play a standard role in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.

NEX method:

  • Nose–Ear–Xiphisternum 
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Approximate length to be inserted: 55cms

Ideally, Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • An abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm the location of the tube

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

Indications for NG tube :

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications:

Absolute:

  • Severe midface trauma
  • Recent nasal surgery

Relative:

  • Coagulation abnormality
  • Esophageal varices
  • Recent banding of esophageal varices
  • Anastomoses in stomach and esophagus

questions.text: A patient is prepared for a minor procedure in the ophthalmology outpatient department. The following instruments are assembled in the tray. Which of the following glands is involved in the pathology for which this procedure is performed?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments represents the chalazion set which is used to perform incision and curettage of a chalazion.

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

A chalazion scoop/curette is another instrument specific to the incision and curettage of a chalazion. It has a small round cup-shaped tip with sharp margins attached to a narrow handle. It is used to scoop out the contents of the chalazion and curette the base after making a vertical incision opening up the wall of the chalazion from its palpebral surface.

A chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the Meibomian gland. A chalazion may be single or multiple. They may reduce in size, but the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur. Treatment of chalazion includes injection of intralesional triamcinolone or curettage.

Sometimes, the chalazion may become secondarily infected and form a hordeolum internum. This is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct. It presents with a swelling similar to a chalazion, but more inflamed with pus pointing on the conjunctival surface. It can be treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and hot fomentation or with an incision and drainage. An image of hordeolum internum is shown below.

Other options :

Options A and D: The gland of Wolfring and the gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands and are not involved in a chalazion.

Option B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done.

questions.text: A patient with bilateral abductor paralysis is admitted to the intensive care unit. In order to relieve the respiratory obstruction, a tracheostomy is being performed. Which of the following is not an immediate complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Tracheal stenosis, due to tracheal ulceration and infection, is a late complication of tracheostomy and does not occur immediately.

A tracheostomy is a procedure where an opening is made in the anterior wall of the trachea and it is converted into a stoma on the skin surface. It is primarily indicated when there is respiratory obstruction, secretions, or respiratory insufficiency. It is also indicated in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks to avoid subglottic stenosis.

Complications of tracheostomy:

Immediate

(at the time of operation)

Intermediate

(during first few hours or days)

Late

(after chronic use for weeks or months)
  1. Primary hemorrhage
  2. Apnoea due to sudden washout of CO2
  3. Pneumothorax due to injury to apical pleura
  4. Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerves
  5. Aspiration of blood
  6. Injury to esopgahus
  1. Reactionary or secondary hemorrhage.
  2. Displacement of the tube.
  3. Blocking of the tube.
  4. Subcutaneous emphysema.
  5. Tracheitis and tracheobronchitis.
  6. Atelectasis and lung abscess.
  7. Local wound infection and granulations.
  1. Laryngeal stenosis.
  2. Tracheal stenosis
  3. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula
  4. Problems of decannulation.
  5. Persistent tracheocutaneous fistula.
  6. Keloid or unsightly scar.
  7. Aspiration of tracheostomy tube fragments into the tracheobronchial tree

 

 

Mentioned below are some instruments used during the procedure. 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

  • It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator.
  • Presence of cuff prevents aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea and also prevents air-leak. 
  • Cuff should be deflated every 2 h for 5 min to prevent ischaemia and damage to the trachea and cartilage necrosis.

Uses:

  • Tracheostomy in an unconscious patient or in a patient on a respirator.

 

Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheal edges open after incision in the trachea so that tracheostomy tube can be easily inserted. 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: The following set of instruments are not used in ________ .
questions.solution:
The given image shows Epidural set, containing an epidural catheter, 18G Tuohy needle and a syringe, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It is used in obstetric analgesia, post-operative analgesia, and segmental blocks, but not in spinal anesthesia.

Identification points:

  • Tuohy needle has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture. The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It finds its use in surgical anesthesia, obstetric analgesia, segmental blocks, post operative analgesia, and chronic pain management.

 Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.
